chat_history.content: : Welcome to Conceptual Academy! I'm Alia, and I'm here to support the learning of core science concepts. Let's get started. How can I help you today?

: Hi Alia. I'm taking a required science course for my degree. I've always been nervous about science classes - I avoided them as much as possible in high school. We're learning about chemistry basics now, and I'm not sure why I should care about it. Does chemistry really matter in everyday life?

: That's a great question! Chemistry absolutely matters in our everyday lives. In fact, let's explore how chemistry is integral to our lives. By definition, chemistry is the study of matter and the transformations it can undergo. Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space. It's the stuff that makes up all material things—anything you can touch, taste, smell, see, or hear is matter. So you can see the scope of chemistry is very broad.
: Wait, so chemistry is about... everything? That's a bit overwhelming. When you say "matter," do you just mean solid objects?

: Not just solid objects. Matter includes anything that has mass and takes up space - so that includes solids, liquids, and gases too. When you wonder what the land, air, or ocean is made of, you're thinking about chemistry. When you wonder how a rain puddle dries up, how a car utilizes the energy of gasoline, or how your body acquires energy from the food you eat, you're again thinking about chemistry.
: Oh, I never thought about it that way. So when I notice my coffee getting cold, that's chemistry too?

: Exactly! That's a perfect everyday example. Chemistry helps explain that process of heat transfer. Chemistry is often described as a central science because it touches all the other sciences. It springs from the principles of physics, and it serves as the foundation for the most complex science of all—biology.
: Biology? I thought biology was about living things and chemistry was about... well, chemicals.

: That's a common misconception. In reality, many of the great advances in the life sciences today, such as genetic engineering, are applications of some very exotic chemistry. Chemistry is also the foundation for earth science. It's an important component of space science too. Just as we learned about the origin of the Moon from the chemical analysis of moon rocks in the early 1970s, we are now learning about the history of Mars and other planets from the chemical information gathered by space probes.
: That's actually pretty cool. I didn't realize chemistry connected to so many fields. Do people really use chemistry in all these different areas?

: Absolutely! There are chemists working in all these fields. Some work as biochemists analyzing DNA profiles, others might be meteorologists studying the chemistry of the upper atmosphere. There are technicians conducting DNA research, paleontologists preserving uncovered ancient fossils, and even astronomers studying the chemical nature of stars.
: So all these different careers use chemistry? I just pictured people in white lab coats mixing colorful liquids.

: That's only one small part of what chemists do. Progress in science is made as scientists conduct research. Research is any activity whose purpose is the discovery of new knowledge. Many scientists focus on basic research, which leads us to a greater understanding of how the natural world operates.
: What kinds of things would be "basic research" in chemistry?
: Basic research in chemistry tells us how atoms combine to form molecules or how the structures of molecules can be determined. This type of research builds our fundamental understanding.
: And I'm guessing there's something called "applied research" too?

: You're catching on quickly! Applied research focuses on the development of useful applications of the knowledge laid down by basic research. The majority of chemists choose applied research as their major focus. Applied research in chemistry has provided us with medicine, food, water, shelter, and so many of the material goods that characterize modern life.
: Hmm, so something like developing a new medicine would be applied research?

: That's correct! Applied research takes that fundamental knowledge and puts it to practical use. For instance, chemists have learned how to produce aspirin using petroleum as a starting material. This is an example of applied research, because the primary goal was to develop a useful commodity. However, the ability to produce aspirin from petroleum depended on an understanding of atoms and molecules developed from many years of basic research.
: But wait - isn't chemistry also responsible for pollution and environmental problems? I've heard a lot about chemicals being bad for the environment.

: That's an important point to address. Over the course of the past century, we became very good at manipulating atoms and molecules to create materials to match our needs. At the same time, however, mistakes were made when it came to caring for the environment. Waste products were dumped into rivers, buried in the ground, or vented into the air without regard for possible long-term consequences. Many people believed that Earth was so large that its resources were virtually unlimited and that it could absorb wastes without being significantly harmed.
: That sounds pretty careless. Has anything changed?

: Yes, there have been significant changes in attitude. Most nations now recognize this as a dangerous attitude. As a result, government agencies, industries, and concerned citizens are involved in extensive efforts to take care of the environment.

For example, members of the American Chemistry Council, who, as a group, produce 90 percent of the chemicals manufactured in the United States, have adopted a program called Responsible Care. Through this program, members of this organization have pledged to manufacture their products without causing environmental damage.
: That's good to hear, but do these programs actually make a difference?

: They can make a substantial difference. Through the wise use of chemistry, waste products can be minimized, recycled, engineered into useful products, or rendered environmentally safe. This is an area of research known as Green Chemistry, which explores how to create chemical processes and products that reduce or eliminate the use and generation of hazardous substances.
: This is making me think differently about chemistry. I never realized how connected it is to everything around us.

: That's exactly right! Chemistry has influenced our lives in many important ways, and it will continue to do so in the future. Most of the material items in any modern house are shaped by some human-devised chemical process. For this reason, it's in everyone's interest to become familiar with the basic concepts of chemistry.

: You know, I was dreading this part of my course, but now I'm actually kind of interested to learn more about how chemistry relates to things in my everyday life. Thanks for helping me see it differently!
: I'm so glad to hear that! Your curiosity is the perfect starting point for learning more about chemistry. Is there a specific aspect of chemistry in everyday life you'd like to explore further?
